item.title: Hummus
item.description:
This hummus is my go-to item to bring for a potluck. It’s super easy to do and damn tasty.

Step 0: Ingredients

  • 2 cans of drained chickpeas (close to 0.5kg)
  • 1 tablespoon of tahini
  • 2 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil
  • 2 tablespoons of Homemade Turkish Yogurt
  • 1 tablespoon of your favorite fresh herb {thyme, basil, mint, oregano} leaves
  • 4 cloves of Garlic
  • Juice of a half lemon
  • Zest of one lemon
  • 1 tablespoon of *smoked paprika*
  • 1 teaspoon of cayenne pepper or any hot pepper flakes
  • Salt and pepper for seasoning.

Step 1: Blend Everything

So simple, mix well everything in the blender. It should be pinkish orange I am trying to say “yavruagzi” in English here. Too sour? add few teaspoons of tahini or olive oil. Too bland? double down on spices. Too tahini-ish? add few teaspoons of yogurt or juice of a lemon. Adjust the seasoning according to your taste.

item.title: Homemade Turkish Yogurt
item.description:
As an expat I am not sure if I should consider myself as expat or immigrant. , I miss sour Turkish yogurt. The best alternative I could find was Bulgarian yogurt trivia: my grandparents from both sides are immigrants from Bulgaria. at Wholefoods. But you can easily make your own sour Turkish yogurt.

Step 0: Ingredients

  • Whole milk as much as your glass container(s) can contain
  • Tablespoon of starter yogurt
  • Thermometer
  • Glass container(s) with a lid
  • Your favorite blanket

Step 1: Boil the Milk

Boil the milk and pour to your containers. Wait till the temperature drops to 115F.

Normally you wouldn’t have to boil milk to get to fermentation temperature if your house is warm enough. But the bacteria working for us are active at 110F - 115F temperatures. Thus, pouring milk to containers while it’s super hot will heat the containers which will help us keep the temperature in the right range longer.

Step 2: Mix the Starter

Take few tablespoons of milk and mixed it with yogurt till the mixture is smooth in a small bowl. Add this mixture to the milk in 115F and stir it gently. Put the lids on, and cover the containers with a blanket. Put it in the warmest spot in your house.

Step 3: Wait

Wait for at least 12 hours while your bacteria are doing their job, then put it in the fridge. Do the tasting after the yogurt is cold.

Optional: Drained Yogurt

For many mezes we prepare for Raki tables There should be a blogpost for Turkish Raki tables and my meze recipes we use a dense version of Yogurt. To get the right viscosity for your mezes, you can pour yogurt to a strainer and keep it in the fridge overnight. The next morning you’ll have a perfect drained yogurt. Do not throw away the water (or juice?) add it to your hummus or shakes.

Optional: DIY Yogurt Machine:

The longer the milk is in the right temperature range, the more sour your yogurt will be. So it is essential to have a setup where you can keep the temperature the same for a long time. Below is an image for my DIY yogurt machine. Here I use a box, styrofoam, and aluminium bag, and styrofoam stand to put the containers in. It works like a charm!

item.title: Filled Artichoke
item.description:
This is an improved version of my mom’s recipe. I’ve never had this recipe in a restaurant, hence the post. Artichokes are so flavorful, you can do few other magical stuff with them, I hope I’ll have time to write those recipes as well. Enjoy!

Step 0: Ingredients

Below is the standard recipe, but you can be more creative with the filling and the broth.

  • 4 artichokes (the leaves on, duh!)
  • 4 cloves of garlic
  • 2 lemons
  • A handful of chopped dill
  • 1 cup of your favorite kind of rice
  • 1 white onion
  • Half tablespoon red pepper paste
  • Half tablespoon tomato paste
  • 2 tablespoon olive oil
  • Salt, pepper, thyme or oregano, cumin.

Step 1: Simmering


When you take the artichokes out do not forget to wash them with cold water so that you do not burn your hands. Boil water, add a juice of a lemon and simmer artichokes lid on in this mix for 30 minutes.

Step 2: Cleaning


The center has baby leaves that are more like spikes or thorn.


Be careful do not put a whole there. Using a spoon, we cut the centerpiece of the artichoke. . Carve this area with your spoon.

Step 3: Preparing Filling

In a bowl, mix rice, chopped onion, dill (save some for dressing), spices, the pastes, and olive oil. This is where you can be creative. If you are an omnivore you can add ground meat.

Step 4: Filling the Artichoke


You can add more tomato paste to the broth. Fill the inside of each leave and the heart of the artichoke with the filling. But a clove of garlic and lemon ring on top of the heart. Add (prefarebly boiling) water and a juice of a half lemon to the bowl, stir it well. Pour this water/lemon juice/paste broth on top of each artichoke.

Step 5: Cooking

Put them on high heat when the broth starts boiling turn it on low and simmer it for 20 minutes. If the rice is soft, they should be ready.

Step 6: Serving

Serve with yogurt and extra plate for the leave wastes. Use leaves as spoons to eat the filling. Use your lower teeth to bite off the meaty part of each leaves.
